body: @reta Why did you make this change? CXF committers have a history with and still use AMQ Classic, I think I'd prefer that this change wasn't made. I'm also a bit confused about the OpenSAML changes in this PR - why were they needed for a change to ActiveMQ?

@coheigea  It looks this is for CXF jakarta namespace change. From [ActiveMQ Artemis embraces Jakarta EE ]( https://blogs.apache.org/activemq/entry/activemq-artemis-embraces-jakarta-ee), Artemis now has the jakarta namespace release.

+1 @coheigea , artemis has no link with ActiveMQ (known as v5) so this is a huge breaking change - we evaluated it at TomEE some years ago and it was not even an option :(. Maybe just request to AMQ project or do in cxf a jakarta shade/relocation which would enable users to not be broken. TomEE did it with success for ex (https://tomee.apache.org/tomee-9.0/docs/jms-resources-and-mdb-container.html) so worse case you can grab the AMQ from tomee too.

@reta Regarding OpenSAML, the work was already done on this branch - https://github.com/apache/cxf/tree/opensaml4, but only in the context of updating to WSS4J 2.5.x / OpenSAML 3.4.x. I think it's better to consider it separately from Artemis.
@coheigea @rmannibucau change reverted , thanks a for promtp feedback!

@reta my 2cts would be to use JMS 1.1 API (JMS 2.0 API is not needed in CXF and does not bring anything AFAIK) and let the user provide the API he wants for most usages. For the distro I would prefer to add one of the AMQ 5 relocation but artemis is fine too there. Note that there are some JMS 2 work for AMQ 5 (mainly importing https://github.com/apache/tomee/tree/master/container/openejb-core/src/main/java/org/apache/openejb/resource/activemq/jms2) so I think it would be worth pinging AMQ guys to get it faster, agree it is really overdue today but in terms of features and deployment I don't think switching the provider is user friendly....until it is not used ;) - but not data on that on my side.

@rmannibucau thanks, I will try to research what are the plans for AMQ Classic / Jakarta and what you guys did in TomEE. The 4.x is for long term, indeed CXF does not need any / most of the JMS 2.0+ features but this is where we see Jakarta going.
@jimma this was/is my understanding as well
@ffang  sorry, another one for you please :)
LGTM!
@rmartinc thank you, I like your solution, will merge in a few days if @dkulp does not find time to look at it

Hey folks. I'm on the ActiveMQ PMC and I can confirm what @jimma has said. The goal of the ActiveMQ community is to make Artemis the next major version of ActiveMQ (i.e. 6.0). 

I'm not clear on the entire use-case here, but if you're embedding ActiveMQ and using it internally then it should be a pretty straight-forward migration assuming you aren't making use of many ActiveMQ-specific features. Looking through @reta's PR it looks pretty much as I would expect.

For what it's worth I'm looking at helping TomEE support ActiveMQ Artemis right now based on a recent [discussion like this](https://lists.apache.org/list?dev@activemq.apache.org:lte=1M:Jakarta%20compatible%20version%20of%20ActiveMQ%20classic) on the ActiveMQ dev list, although I've been covered up with other work recently.

I think the sooner projects like CXF, TomEE, etc. migrate the better position we'll _all_ be in. At the very least it will reduce pressure on ActiveMQ to duplicate work on the "Classic" broker that's already been done on Artemis.

I'm willing to answer any questions anybody has, technical or otherwise, about CXF's potential migration to Artemis. I would volunteer to help with the coding, but @reta seems to have that in hand already.

Thanks a lot @jbertram, it sounds very reassuring, thank you for confirming. There are 2 migration paths which I have not addressed yet:
 - Artemis + JTA (Jakarta TM)
 - Alternative to ActiveMQ Advisories [1], do you happen to know if there are replacements in Artemis? If you ask me why we got it in the first place - I don't know that exactly (yet), besides reversing engineering the implementation.

Thanks a mill!

[1] https://activemq.apache.org/advisory-message

Hi @jbertram for what it's worth:

1. Tomee already runs well with artemis if you add it
2. Migration for users is almost always hard or impossible for a tons of reasons (particular feature missing - there are still a lot, undesired dependencies, too huge stack, too much "new" redhat stuff/"not apache" dep - important for support for ex, unsupported protocol, inexperience of ops, too hard/impossible smooth migration on existing clusters - hundreds of instances are not rare, less smoother getting started, ...).

I know goal of amq 6 was to make it converging but it never happent since the creation even if a lot of - good - efforts had been done so i would be very cautious with such statements.
As mentionned, code migration can be 1h or alike, rest will never happen and we were talking of distro so prod so think we should stick to amq5 still since artemis didnt manage to replace it in adoption yet.

@rmannibucau if you remember, we have discussed to have `javax.*` branch (talking about CXF specifically), in sync with `jakarta.*` one. We have not done anything in this direction just yet, but won't be this path a viable option for ones who would stay on AMQ 5.x ?

@reta agree but think it will be the exception confirming the general rule (:()). I also saw a ticket for AMQ 5 moving to jakarta but agree overall that javax -> AMQ5 (too much users), jakarta -> artemis (new users since it requires migration effort anyway). There is also this topic about splitting cxf in modules, I strongly think JMS integration can be extracted since it almost never moves, wdyt? My overall goal is to keep AMQ 5 user having a functional distro and not have to start doing it manually for the time cxf maintains javax branch.

@reta 

> Artemis + JTA (Jakarta TM)

As far as I know this should work fine.

> Alternative to ActiveMQ Advisories [1], do you happen to know if there are replacements in Artemis?

Artemis has [management notifications](https://activemq.apache.org/components/artemis/documentation/latest/management.html#management-notifications), as well as the the [NotificationActiveMQServerPlugin](https://activemq.apache.org/components/artemis/documentation/latest/broker-plugins.html#using-the-notificationactivemqserverplugin) (which expands the kinds of notifications which are sent). However, that's not a direct replacement for advisory messages and may not fit your need depending on what you're using advisories for. We can discuss further if needed.
Thanks @dblevins !
@coheigea we could close this one, right? we are on JDK-11 already

@reta Thanks a lot for merging! I see in the JIRA that this is expected in 3.4.7 and 3.5.2 too. But we are also interested in 3.3.x (EAP 7). Is it possible to include the JIRA in 3.3.x-fixes? I can send any backport PR to the other branches if needed...

> @reta Thanks a lot for merging! I see in the JIRA that this is expected in 3.4.7 and 3.5.2 too. But we are also interested in 3.3.x (EAP 7). Is it possible to include the JIRA in 3.3.x-fixes? I can send any backport PR to the other branches if needed...

```
3.3.13 is the last planned release for the Apache CXF 3.3.x series.   Users are strongly recommended to upgrade to 3.5.x.
```

I could backport the change to 3.3.x but it is unlikely to be released.

[1] https://cxf.apache.org/download.html


>  - There are references to the old Jackson provider in systests/rs-security on CXF-8371 that could be updated.

or use explicit threshold value in the test instead:
`Object cache = createCache(64 * 1024);`

Yes, that would work as well. I suggested the other way because almost all the tests use the default `createCache()`, so I thought that the test was trying to test the system property and the threshold as well. I have made a new commit that uses your suggestion. Please let me know if you have any other comments.

Could see a few things:

system.properties:
```
org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.localRepository=/home/jenkins/workspace/CXF/CXF-JDK11-PR/.repository
```

/home/jenkins/workspace/CXF/CXF-JDK11-PR/.repository has `cxf-tools-compiler` published but the bundle is not installed: 

```
karaf@root()> la | grep -i compiler
karaf@root()>
```

Looking why PAX does not seem to pick the artifacts.

> I wrongly saw this CI result : https://ci-builds.apache.org/job/CXF/job/CXF-JDK11-PR/109/, it's still using JDK11 to run. It's good to fix this too. WDYT ?

This is the right place since this is a PR build (but we also build `origin` branch pipelines). The thing is, this is our main Jenkins check for `master` - basically where we have all pull requests coming. For `javax.*` we will stay on JDK-11 baseline (as we discussed [1]) so it is probably makes sense to keep it that way. But ... for Jakarta branch (4.0.0) we would need it to use JDK-17 and to be fair, I have not succeeded yet to configure separate pull request builders for different branches. I mean, I could create Jenkins jobs for different branch specs but only one of the jobs triggers. Will be looking into that shortly.

[1] https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@cxf.apache.org/msg17023.html
